org.grouplens.lenskit.cursors

Class AbstractPollingCursor<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.grouplens.lenskit.cursors.AbstractCursor<T>
      • org.grouplens.lenskit.cursors.AbstractPollingCursor<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T -
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.lang.Iterable<T>, Cursor<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DelimitedTextRatingCursor, LineCursor

    public abstract class AbstractPollingCursor<T>
extends AbstractCursor<T>
    An extension of AbstractCursor that simplifies the mechanics of the next()/hasNext() implementation to a simple method, poll().

    Compatibility: Public

    • Method Detail

      • hasNext

        public boolean hasNext()
        Description copied from interface: Cursor
        Query whether the cursor has any more items. If the cursor or underlying source has been closed, this may return even if the end has not been reached.
        Returns:
        true if there remains another item to fetch.

      • fastNext

        @Nonnull
@Deprecated
public T fastNext()
        Deprecated. 
        Description copied from class: AbstractCursor
        Variant of Cursor.next() that may mutate and return the same object avoid excess allocations. Since many loops don't do anything with the object after the iteration in which it is retrieved, using this iteration method can improve both speed and memory use.

        This implementation delegates to Cursor.next().

        Specified by:
        fastNext in interface Cursor<T>
        Overrides:
        fastNext in class AbstractCursor<T>
        Returns:
        The next element from the cursor, reusing objects if possible.
        See Also:
        Cursor.next()

      • next

        @Nonnull
public T next()
        Description copied from interface: Cursor
        Fetch the next item from the cursor.
        Returns:
        The next item in the cursor.

      • poll

        protected abstract T poll()
        Return the next element in this Cursor, or null if there are no more elements. This must be safe to call multiple times at the end of its collection. The same element object is allowed to be reused (fast iteration), so long as copy(Object) copies objects. If this method returns a fresh object every time, then copy(Object) should be a no-op.
        Returns:
        The next element, or null

      • copy

        protected T copy(T obj)
        Construct a copy of an object. The default does not copy; it just returns its parameter. If a subclass wants to fast iteration to actually be fast (mutate and reuse the same object), it should do so in its poll() method, and override this method to create a new copy of an object for when next() is called. Subclasses which return fresh objects on each call to poll() do not need to override this method.
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to copy.
        Returns:
        A copy of obj.
